⁣
1.  Promotes innovation and creativity.⁣
2.  Breaks down stigma and stereotypes.⁣
3.  Creates a more equitable and just society.⁣
⁣
Let's embrace neurodiversity as an aspect of human diversity. ⁣

text:
Differences are neutral. Diversity is valuable. 

For example, neurotype differences (being neurotypical or neurodivergent) are not good or bad. They are value-neutral. And neurodiversity adds value to the world, just as all diversity does.

text: @AuthorConfusion Depends on context. Neurodiversity refers to the movement to include other neurotypes as normal variants of people, and includes all neurotypes including neurotypical people. Neurodivergence refers to people who aren't neurotypical - which includes a lot of things, including 1/2

text: @MazMcCaffrey @ItaOKelly @IrishTimes If your child is stressed out, why is the teacher not making accommodations for them? A child with unacknowledged neurodiversity, dyslexia, dyspraxia, ADHD for example will struggle. Good teachers would pick up on these possible reasons, it's even more obvious through homework.

@shaunziegenfusz @DrHannahHobson For what it’s worth, I think being ‘neurodivergent’ is perceived as being more acceptable to, and in, society than having a ‘disability’. In many ways neurodiversity is embraced whereas, disappointingly, ‘disability’ or ‘disorder’ are not.

text:
2. Avoid labeling:

Neurodiversity can’t be shoved into a label or a box–it’s more of a spectrum of needs, hence the name.

So, instead of jumping to conclusions on how best to care for someone’s needs, listen, and take note of their preferences.

user_description: Monotropic semi speaking adult writing about neurodivergent life & sharing his adventures. MTB, Triker, AAC user, bouncy, podcast host & lion tamer (he/him/it)

text:
Part of why I prefer the neurodiversity lens in general is that it identifies the barriers as being in the environment not the person.

Everyone is part of neurodiversity & has environmental needs.
